text: When I have multiple tasks, I choose one main task and hold it as my anchor before switching.
I recognize when it's time to switch tasks based on natural boundaries, not random impulses.
When I switch between tasks, I freeze the context of the previous task so I can resume it easily later.
I let multiple tasks compete for attention without choosing a main focus, and I switch randomly without structure.
When I notice cognitive load building up, I reduce friction and clear my workspace before continuing.
I recognize the difference between tasks that need immediate attention and tasks that can wait.
When I group tasks by similar mental modes, switching becomes smoother and faster.
I let interruptions pull me away from my main task without pausing to decide if they need attention now or later.
When I predict potential bottlenecks before they appear, I stay ahead of problems and switch more efficiently.
I recognize when my cognitive bandwidth is getting full, and I manage it like a limited resource.
When I create task loops with clear patterns like focus, check, switch, and reset, multitasking becomes predictable.
I try to handle too many active tasks at once without limiting myself, and I overload my mental capacity.
When I assign each task a clear home or category, I reduce switching cost and maintain better organization.
I recognize when switching too early or too late is affecting my efficiency, and I adjust my timing.
When I work in focused blocks with controlled switching windows, I match my natural cognitive cycles.
I let hidden friction like clutter, notifications, or unclear goals drain my attention without addressing them.
When I separate tasks by mode, I avoid conflicts between thinking, execution, and communication tasks.
I recognize when my task state is messy before switching, and I clean it up to make resumption easier.
When I limit myself to a maximum of two active tasks, I prevent cognitive overload and maintain clarity.
I switch tasks without freezing context or reducing cognitive load, and I struggle to resume previous tasks.
